thread.title: Melbourne v Carlton, JLT Community Series, AFL 2017: Concern over Blues | Fox Sports
thread.title_full: Melbourne v Carlton, JLT Community Series, AFL 2017: Concern over Blues | Fox Sports

author: February
title: Melbourne v Carlton, JLT Community Series, AFL 2017: Concern over Blues | Fox Sports
text:
IT’S one thing to lose a JLT Community Series game. 
It’s another to go down in the fashion Carlton did on Saturday afternoon. 
Yes it was their first pre-season game of the year, but things didn’t go to plan for the Blues at Casey Fields, going down to Melbourne in disappointing circumstances. 
The Demons ran away with a comprehensive 54-point win against the Blues — the biggest margin of this year’s JLT Community Series so far. 
What made the scoreboard look even worse for the Blues was the fact Melbourne’s score — 17.14 (116) — was its highest score in a pre-season competition since 2000. 
And what concerned the Fox Footy commentary team the most — especially Hawthorn legend Jason Dunstall — was the amount of easy goals the Blues conceded throughout the match. 
Of the 17 goals the Demons kicked, six of them came from inside, or just outside, the goalsquare, with many Melbourne forwards often finding themselves free to convert easy majors. 
“As good as they (the Demons) have been, the question marks are starting to be raised (for the Blues),” Dunstall told Fox Footy during the third term. 
Dunstall’s criticism of Brendon Bolton’s men came after another easy goal was scored by the Demons from the goalsquare, with two Demons almost fighting among themselves for the score. In the end, Jesse Hogan won out over Sam Weideman to kick one of his three goals for the afternoon. 
“Carlton’s defensive structure has been poor,” Dunstall said. Blues coach Brendon Bolton addresses his players against Melbourne. Source: Getty Images 
“The amount of times they’ve been caught out over the back and not been able to stop Melbourne going forward … I wonder where are all the loose Carlton players are, because Melbourne have got loose players everywhere,” 
Champion St Kilda full-back Danny Frawley added: “They’re like witches hats at the moment.” 
For Dunstall, the biggest issue surrounded the club’s workrate. 
While the Demons, as you’d expect, racked up more disposals (+21) than the Blues, they also finished with way more tackles (+11) 
“It’s an indictment on the workrate of the Blues,” Dunstall said. 
“It’s a long road ahead for the Blues … and he certainly won’t shy away from that, Brendon Bolton.” 
As disappointing as the Blues were, Melbourne was just as impressive. 
Christian Petracca was again a standout, booting four goals — and having a hand in seven other scores — from 19 touches and 10 contested possessions. 
Hogan (3.1) was excellent up forward, while Nathan Jones, Jake Melksham, Bernie Vince, Jordan Lewis, Christian Salem and Clayton Oliver all finished with 20 touches or more. 
But Bolton and his fellow Blues coaches will undoubtedly be busy this week reviewing Saturday’s performance. 
“They’re a long way off,” Dunstall said post-game. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
